result.markdown:
--- title: "Efficiently Cleaning and Labelling Columns with `thekidsbiostats`" author: "Zac Dempsey, Dr Robin van de Meeburg" format: html: code-fold: true tabset: true toc: true toc-location: left date: "2026-02-12" categories: - R - Data cleaning - Package draft: true css: _extensions/html/styles.css editor_options: chunk_output_type: inline execute: echo: false warning: false fig-align: center fig-format: png --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(thekidsbiostats) # install with install.packages("thekidsbiostats", repos = "the-kids-biostats.r-universe.dev") ``` ::: # Overview Datasets rarely come with cleaned, tidy formatting in their column names. It is common practice to rename the original column names to something more syntactic, code-friendly names (i.e., lower-case, no spaces or special characters and unique). Alongside code-friendly columns, it is also often useful to store *label attributes*, which provide clean, human-readable versions labels for each code-friendly variable for use in analytical reports, tables and figures. While a variety of functions for *renaming columns* (e.g. `dplyr::rename()`) and *applying labels* (e.g., using the [`labelled`](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/labelled/index.html) or [`Hmisc`](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/Hmisc/index.html) packages) exist, there is still a reasonable amount of leg work needed before such functions can be applied. This post will demonstrates how the process of standardising and labelling columns can be streamlined and expedited. Specifically, we will introduce use two main functions from [`thekidsbiostats`](https://github.com/The-Kids-Biostats/thekidsbiostats): + [`make_column_dict()`](https://the-kids-biostats.github.io/thekidsbiostats/reference/make_column_dict.html) –-- create a copy-pasteable column dictionary template. + [`update_columns()`](https://the-kids-biostats.github.io/thekidsbiostats/reference/update_columns.html) –-- rename and label columns using a column dictionary. # Motivating Example As an example, let's point to the `data_patient` dataset, which is conveniently contained in `thekidsbiostats` package: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data(data_patient, package = "thekidsbiostats") ``` ::: Previewing this dataset: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Patient ID#

DOB [YYYY-MM-DD]

Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)

WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)

WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)

Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?

bp (mmHg)

Cholesterol / mmolL

101

1980‑05‑12

0

175

70

true

120/80

5.2

102

1992‑08‑03

1

160

55

false

110/70

4.8

103

1975‑12‑25

1

180

80

false

130/85

6.1

104

2000‑01‑01

0

165

60

true

115/75

5.0

105

1985‑07‑07

1

170

75

false

125/82

5.5

``` ::: ::: Immediately, we see that the column headers are not formatted in a very nice way. The column headers contain (any number of): + Categorical variable coding + Full questions + Spacing + Inconsistent letter capitalisation + Punctuation (parentheses, equals signs, questions marks, dashes, slashes) The spaces and punctuation in these column names require us to use backticks (``) to avoid R interpreting these symbols literally. Beyond visually looking messy, it can also be time consuming and tricky to reference these column names when attempting to use them in operations. For example, using the original column names, let's implement two trivial manipulations/changes to the data: ::: panel-tabset ## i) Calculate BMI ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_patient$bmi <- data_patient$`WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)` / (data_patient$`WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)` / 100.0)^2 ``` ::: ## ii) Re-Code `Sex` Recode the Sex column by replacing 0/1 with Male/Female, as defined in the existing column header. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` = case_when( data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` == 0 ~ "Male", data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` == 1 ~ "Female", TRUE ~ NA_character_ ) ``` ::: ::: ::: column-margin Clearly, coding each of these changes are cumbersome and time intensive, and can restrict the readability of our code workflow. ::: Functions such as `janitor::clean_names()` can be very useful for standardising such column names into syntactic names. However, this approach is still imperfect, and the resulting names may remain just as problematic (as seen below). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_patient |> select(6) |> janitor::clean_names() %>% colnames(.) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "do_you_currently_smoke_any_form_of_tobacco_products_including_cigarettes_cigars_or_pipes_on_a_regular_basis" ``` ::: ::: ::: column-margin The "cleaned" version of this column name simply omits spaces and punctuation, and is still far too long. ::: ## Create Data Dictionary ::: callout-important Renaming columns for easy manipulation in code is potentially dropping any useful formatting of the columns (e.g., units and symbols). Ideally, we want to both rename the columns and simultaneously retain their human-readable labels for presentation/reporting. ::: Our solution to this is therefore to manually set up a dictionary that maps the **old column names** to **newly formatted column names** as well as **apply label attributes**. The `make_column_dict()` function makes this process slightly easier by creating a ready-to-fill template based on the column names that exist with the data. For example: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict <- make_column_dict(data = data_patient, auto_clean = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` dict_patient <- tribble( ~old, ~new, ~label, 'Patient ID#', 'patient_id_number', '', 'DOB [YYYY-MM-DD]', 'dob_yyyy_mm_dd', '', 'Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)', 'sex_0_male_1_female', '', 'WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)', 'what_is_your_height_cm', '', 'WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)', 'what_is_your_current_weight_kg', '', 'Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?', 'do_you_currently_smoke_any_form_of_tobacco_products_including_cigarettes_cigars_or_pipes_on_a_regular_basis', '', 'bp (mmHg)', 'bp_mm_hg', '', 'Cholesterol / mmolL', 'cholesterol_mmol_l', '', 'bmi', 'bmi', '', ) ``` ::: ::: We can either directly add to, or modify, the `dict` object (as assigned above) or copy-paste the printed output into our code and modify the new column names and labels as needed: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict_patient <- tribble( ~old, ~new, ~label, 'Patient ID#', 'id', 'Patient ID', 'DOB [YYYY-MM-DD]', 'dob', 'Date of Birth', 'Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)', 'sex', 'Sex', 'WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)', 'height_cm', 'Height (cm)', 'WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)', 'weight_kg', 'Weight (kg)', 'Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?', 'current_smoking', 'Current tobacco consumption', 'bp (mmHg)', 'bp_mmhg', 'BP (mmHg)', 'Cholesterol / mmolL', 'cholesterol_mmol_l', 'Cholesterol (mmolL)', ) ``` ::: Alternatively, we can also write this file (e.g., csv, rds, xlsx) to our machine, by specifying `file`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} make_column_dict(data = data_patient, auto_clean = TRUE, file = "colnames.csv") ``` ::: And then read the csv back in after new column names and labels have been added: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict_patient <- readr::read_csv(file = "colnames.csv") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

old

new

label

Patient ID#

id

Patient ID

DOB [YYYY‑MM‑DD]

dob

Date of Birth

Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)

sex

Sex

WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)

height_cm

Height (cm)

WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)

weight_kg

Weight (kg)

Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?

current_smoking

Current tobacco consumption

bp (mmHg)

bp_mmhg

BP (mmHg)

Cholesterol / mmolL

cholesterol_mmoll

Cholesterol (mmolL)

``` ::: ::: ## Apply column dictionary Now that we have defined the column dictionary above, we can simply use the `update_columns()` function to apply these changes in a single line. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_clean <- update_columns(data_patient, dict = dict_patient) ``` ::: ::: column-margin The "default" names for the old, new and label attributes bust ::: Previewing this "cleaned" dataset: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

id

dob

sex

height_cm

weight_kg

current_smoking

bp_mmhg

cholesterol_mmoll

bmi

125/82

25.95156

``` ::: ::: Because the labels we specified are stored as attributes, they are automatically recognised by many summary packages that respect label metadata (e.g., `gtsummary::tbl_summary()` tables). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Characteristic

N = 51

bmi

22.86 (22.04, 24.69)

1n (%); Median (Q1, Q3)

``` ::: ::: # Closing comments Overall, the `make_column_dict()` and `update_columns()` functions from our package offer an efficient solution for transforming and labelling datasets with problematic column headers. More concise column names are easier to work with and enhance the readability/tractability of code, while user-defined labels allow users to easily produce more polished and publication-ready tables and figures. # Acknowledgements Thanks to Dr Matt Cooper, Wesley Billingham, Dr Robin Cook and Dr Elizabeth McKinnon for providing feedback on and reviewing this post. ## Reproducibility Information To access the .qmd (Quarto markdown) files as well as any R scripts or data that was used in this post, please visit our GitHub: The session information can also be seen below. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sessionInfo() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` R version 4.5.0 (2025-04-11 ucrt) Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 Running under: Windows 10 x64 (build 19045) Matrix products:
